titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Theresa Helburn Papers
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke Staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday January 23, 2019 at 05:12

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Theresa Helburn Papers consist of correspondence, diaries, financial documents, writings, photographs, scrapbooks and memorabilia documenting her career as a writer and theatrical director and administrator for the Theatre Guild and other theaters.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Margaret (Mrs. Eric) Kocher and other Kocher family members, 1966-2010.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Theresa Helburn Papers are the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Theresa Helburn Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.

The collection is comprised of material formerly classed as Uncat ZA Helburn, Uncat ZA File Helburn, Uncat MSS 959, and Uncat MSS 1245. Additional Helburn papers were identified in the Theatre Guild Archive (YCAL MSS 436) during the processing of those papers. These materials have not been merged and organized as a whole, but are described separately in the contents list below, according to the source of acquisition.

Information included in the Description of Papers note and Collection Contents section is drawn from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during basic processing.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

relatedmaterial.head: Associated Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Associated material: Theatre Guild Archive (YCAL MSS 436). Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

bioghist.head: Theresa Helburn (1887-1959)
bioghist.p: Theresa Helburn was born in New York City in 1887, graduated from Bryn Mawr College in 1908, and had an early career as a writer of essays, poetry, and plays, and as a theatre critic for the The Nation . In 1919, she joined the Theatre Guild in New York City as a play reader. Within a few years she was co-administrative director with Lawrence Langner. As a writer, critic, director, and administrator, Theresa Helburn was a major force in the development of twentieth-century American theatre. She was married to the writer and teacher John Baker Opdycke (Oliver to his friends) from 1921 until his death in 1958. Helburn died in 1959.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Theresa Helburn Papers consist of correspondence, diaries, financial documents, writings, photographs, scrapbooks and memorabilia documenting her career as a writer and theatrical director and administrator for the Theatre Guild and other theatres.

The correspondence in the collection is predominately personal, and includes letters from Carlotta O'Neill describing her husband's illness, a typed copy of an exchange between Helburn and George Bernard Shaw regarding her work in the film industry, and a letter from Shaw's assistant, Blanche Patch, describing the playwright's death. Helburn's diaries and date books include short entries about her meetings, travel, and social events, and often contain references to her health and the weather. Financial documents provide information regarding not only her daily personal expenses, but her own financial investment in Theatre Guild productions as well as in stocks and oil. Helburn's writing career is documented by early notes and story ideas, drafts and published versions of articles and presentations, poetry, and autobiographical essays, including those published in The Nation . Her work in, and opinions about, the film industry are described in drafts of articles and in the film story ideas, synopses, and comments that Helburn either wrote or reviewed while working in Hollywood at Columbia Pictures in mid-1930s.

While there is one file of material relating to Helburn's autobiography (which was completed and published after her death), the most substantial biographical information regarding her professional life is found in the scrapbooks that Helburn maintained from 1919 to 1950. Newspaper and magazine clippings of articles by and about Helburn, performance programs from the plays she wrote and/or directed, along with other miscellaneous ephemera, illuminate her many activities in the world of literature, theatre, and film. The papers also include photographs of family members, friends and colleagues, as well as candid and portrait photographs of Helburn. Material post-dating Helburn's death, including condolence letters, obituaries, and records pertaining to her estate, was added by family members.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Papers are organized in three groupings: I. Pre-2010 Acquisitions,1903-1958 . II. Material Formerly Part of the Theatre Guild Archive, 1918-1958. III. 2010 Acquisitions, 1887-1992.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Personal Files are organized into four subcategories: Correspondence, Diaries, Financial Records, and Photographs

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Writings are arranged alphabetically within three subcategories: Articles, Poetry, and Presentations; Film Story Ideas, Treatments, Synopses, and Comments; and Notes

did.unittitle: Autobiographical essays, drafts, typescript and holograph, corrected
"The Aviator," a poem published in The Bellman , Volume XX, number 500

"From One Guild to Another," published version in Opera News
"Mother," published version of poem clipped by the Romeike press clipping bureau from numerous U.S. newspapers
"On Experiment," draft, typescript carbon, 1946 Jul 29 and published version from the The New York Times 1946 Aug 4
"O'Neill: an Impression," published version published in The Saturday Review of Literature
"Some Random Musings on Bright College Years," draft, typescript, corrected
["The Theatre, Bloody but Unbowed,"] drafts, typescript and carbon, corrected (published in the North American Review Summer 1937)

"Theatre Versus Pictures," draft, typescript, and published version from the Journal of the American Association of University Women 1936 January; accompanied by notes and typescript drafts of essays comparing theatre and film
"To You," printed version of poem published in The Poetry Journal
"What's in a Title?," printed version, published in Leblang's Theatre Bulletin
Film story ideas, treatments, synopses, and comments

scopecontent.p: Consist of drafts, typescript, some corrected and/or annotated.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes holograph notes and quotations; notes for plays and story ideas; and outlines for courses on plays and modern poetry, accompanied by an annotated 1916 program of lectures at The Manor Club

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Scrapbooks are arranged chronologically; Memorabilia is arranged alphabetically by subject.
